#define NUM_ARGS   6

The number of arguments that this program will take from the expression stack.

Function Documentation

float riemann_sum ( ESI  expression,
ESI  var,
float  lower_bounds,
float  upper_bounds,
unsigned int  numsteps,
float  offset 
)

Returns the Riemann sum of the argument "expression". The "var" argument is the variable which changes; it is analagus to the variable of integration. The bounds are determind by lower_bounds and upper_bounds, and the number of steps is determined by numsteps. Assuming left Riemann sums are the default operation, offset * dx (with var as x), will be added to the location of every sampling point. This effectively shifts over the location on which the sum is being taken. Thus, for example, one could do a right riemann sum by setting offset to 1.

float trap_rule ( ESI  expression,
ESI  var,
float  lower_bounds,
float  upper_bounds,
unsigned int  numsteps 
)

This function is very similar to riemann_sum, except that it computes the trapezoid rule instead, and * has no "offset" argument, because there are no variations on the trapeziod rule.

float value_at_point ( ESI  expression,
ESI  var,
float  x 
)

Returns the float value of expression, when var is set to the value x.
